reviewText: This workout is fun. The first part is a regular kundalini yoga set, which will always make you feel great. The second part introduces some dance moves, but encourages you to experiment, as well. It is nice to move beyond following instructions into listening and honoring the body to move as it needs to express itself.
summary: add some creativity to your yoga practice
Title: N/A

reviewText: So I was interested in trying a different kind of yoga DVD. I really liked Gaurmukh Khalsa's videos, so kundalini was on my mind. I bought it, but when I viewed the entire dvd, I was disappointed. The first portion seemed too easy (physically) and the dance portion seemed way too unstructured to be effective. I was partly wrong. Some practitioners looking for a very rigorous workout will find this too light and unchallenging. But, if you're looking for a medium workout, this is good. The stretches in the beginning are easy going, but the dance workout isn't necessarily easy if you're doing the entire thing. Moving your arms consantly for thirty minutes straight isn't as relaxing as it sounds.As for the cheeziness factor of the instructor's outfits and styles. It could be noted that many dvds feature female instructors wearing little clothing and more skin. This instructor just seems to have a body type the current era of marketing tends to favor, so Ana Brett receives more attention for it. She is very aesthetically marketable, but somehow I don't feel her look is plastic.As for the narration of Ravi Singh and her movements coinciding...it does give off a whiff of sexuality. If you find that distracting, then you shouldn't use this tape. I do agree with some viewers that feel it is very sexual. However, I do not know whether the instructors are conscious of it as they are doing it. That they are giving off such a sexual vibe. I just went with the flow and did the work out, and I found it to be tiring without being overly taxing.
summary: Surprisingly good - not the best Kundalini DVD out there, but good

reviewText: This is an amazing workout.  Please be open minded when you first try this exercise at home.  First time, I did not know what to think of it.  I did not do the whole workout. Then, I tried it again and this time I did the whole workout. Finally, I realized how great the experience is... I cannot help but keep smiling all day long.Update: I have been using this workout as a reward for myself.  I have been trying to set up an exercise routine for over ten months now.  If I do four workouts in a week, I do this one as a reward.  Not in a million years, would I think that I see an exercise routine as a reward for doing my daily exercise.An Old Queen of Excuses for Not Exercising

reviewText: Although I actually took a Kundalini yoga workshop with instructors Ana Brett and Ravi Singh in 2005, this was the first of their DVDs that I tried, as my home practice tends to consist of more traditional forms of Hatha yoga.  To my surprise, I enjoyed this DVD very much, and I expect that I will now include some Kundalini as part of my home practice.Unlike their live workshops, Ana and Ravi's DVDs feature Ana only on screen, with both Ana and Ravi providing instruction via voiceover.  Dance the Chakras is broken down into two main sections, a Kundalini yoga sequence and a series of short guided dances.  The DVD chapter menu breaks down as follows (I've added approximate times and brief details):IntroductionTune In (just under 3 minutes)--includes ong namo guru dev namo chantYoga Set 1 (9.5 minutes)--stomach grinds, ragdoll (fast head-to-knee pose performed repeatedly), crow (a type of squat, not an arm balance) with Breath of Fire [BOF], butterfly with forward bend, bridge with BOF; includes brief pauses to meditate throughoutYoga Set 2 (16 minutes)--moving legs in and out while lying on back, rolling, chest expansion (arms raised at right angles move in and out) with BOF, arms held at 60 degrees, shoulderstand with BOF, plow, rolling, neck rolls, cat/cow sequence, baby pose (child's pose) with arm mudra and 3-part breath; includes brief pauses to meditate throughoutShake Your Chakras:Tribal Dance (5 minutes)--arms opening, surfer dips (rock down and back up), tribal dance (pulse arms down, work your way up)Hippy Hippy Shake (3.5 minutes)--hips shake side-side-side-up, hip rolls up to one side, side to side swaysFunky Temple Dance (3.5 minutes)--free form, with side sweeps and other large arm movementsDance of Power (4.5 minutes)--punches, victory dance, sweep kicksRock Your Soul:Heart (2.5 minutes)--includes spinningTrance Dance (4 minutes)--freeform dance with sat-a-nam wahay guru chantDeep Relaxation (3 minutes)--relaxation poseChakra Mudra Chant (5 minutes; also called mantra meditation)--repeated arm movement pattern while singing ap sahae hoa-suchay da sucha doa-har har harClosing Prayer (1 minute)--pray for self, other, world peaceAlthough I don't have much experience with Kundalini yoga, many of the postures included in the yoga sets were familiar, and I enjoyed the mix of fast repetitions with more slow relaxed holds.  Ana and Ravi talk about which chakras are being worked via each exercise, moving from the lower body to the top of the head.  I was more wary of the dance section: although I do enjoy some dance workouts, I tend not to like more freeform workouts.  Surprisingly, I found that these dances were really enjoyable, particularly the Hippy Hippy Shake, with all of its fun hip swings and sways, and the Dance of Power, which had a bit of a kickboxing flavor.  Ana's moves are sensual and free, and although I did try to follow her, I didn't feel pressured to copy her exactly either.  The chakra mudra meditation was another pleasant surprise that left me feeling very relaxed and focused.The entire workout comes in at about 60 minutes.  However, the DVD also includes some great pre-sets (premixes) which give you several different shorter workout options.  These include Shake Your Chakras, 30 minutes; Chakra Light, 30 minutes; Sweat and Glow, 45 minutes; and Angel Tango, 20 minutes.  However, you might find that you enjoy the DVD so much that you want to do the entire thing!  I think that fans of Ana and Ravi will definitely love this DVD, but I also would recommend it for those new to Kundalini who approach the practice with an open mind and spirit.
summary: Enjoyable and relaxing combination of Kundalini yoga and guided dance

reviewText: I just finished doing this DVD and it's just PERFECT!!!!! What a great workout for the body and the soul.... this DVD elevates my mood like no other!!! This should get 10 stars!!!!! It's soooo much fun!!!!!!I love the kundalini yoga set for the charkas (it's about 30 min). It includes shoulder stands, crow pose with breath of fire, among others.... then the real fun starts with the dance the charkas set!!!! I had such a great time doing these sets.... Ana demonstrates different dances, really easy to follow.... It's so freeing.... The DVD has 6 different dances you can choose from. One of my favorite dances was the Tribal dance and Rock your soul (heart) dance.... amazing!!! I also loved the mantra meditation, simply beautiful!!!!A great bonus is the incorporation of 4 pre-set workouts into the DVD... two 30 min. workouts, one 45 min. and one 20 min workout!!! This is great for when I don't have enough time to do the entire DVD!!! Just Brilliant!!!Congratulations Ana & Ravi for this wonderful work!!!!!

reviewText: This is a great combo of a full 30 minute yoga work out and a low impact dance workout that is a whole lot of FUN! You will feel it in your legs, and arms and stomach and you will also experience a great hip opening and stretch! Ana & Ravi give great instruction for the dance moves and lets you know that learning the exact move is not as iimportant as to keep moving which is the point. You do African style moves for the first center, more sensous movement for the second, martial style kicks and arm thrusts for the 3rd (power Chakra) and then more gentle movements for the heart center. I felt I had never really experienced the joy of dance till I experienced moving with Ana in this program!
summary: Love this Workout & appreciate the great music!

reviewText: I really enjoy this DVD. I espeically like how it is split up into sections---you can elect to do the whole DVD, a 45-minute workout, 30-minute workout, 20 minute workout....it's nice to have options for variety.Personally, I am an absolute klutz with no rhythym, so I was wary when I bought a DVD with "dance" in the title. However, I was looking for something different and was willing to give it a try (plus, all of the 5-star ratings were encouraging). To all of you who are definitely not dancers like me: no worries! The dance moves are *not* coreographed, hard-to-learn moves...they're very free-flowing and actually kinda fun to do. It's less like a dance and more like moving freely and letting yourself go. The yoga part is really good too--nothing too fancy, yet you can still use modifications to make the moves more difficult if you so choose.I would feel like an absolute moron doing this DVD in front of or with other people, but I really enjoy it in privacy. It does get my heart rate up, and it's great on days that I can't make it to the gym. I highly recommend it.

reviewText: I'm not what I consider the 'yoga' type, I prefer more sweaty physical type workouts, but I wanted something I could do before work at 6:oo am.  All the reviews were great, so I gave it a try.  I watched it first to get familiarized, and was kind of put off by all the chanting and singing, but hey, if no one's around to make you feel like an idiot, why not?  I really enjoyed the workout, and for the time crunched the preset workouts are awesome.  With all the low bending and throwing your upper body around I worried about back injuries, but my back actually felt great.  I love the breath of fire, too.  Music is good, cueing is good, set was kind of 60-s minimalist, but it matched Ana perfectly.I'm hooked!
Title: N/A

reviewText: While I've enjoyed all of the Ravi and Ana releases I've gotten my hands on, this is probably the most fun workout they've put out.It is also, as is the case with many of their releases, very easy to break up.  The first section is a "yoga workout" that moves up through the chakras- I want to say each chakra gets two movements, or so.  This section takes a little under thirty minutes.  Although I love Yoga Beauty Body- so much so that I can't shut up about it in many of reviews- I have reached for this one quite a bit when I want the same kind of comprehensive workout that one gives but in less time.  As a bonus, this DVD also includes a cat/cow sequence, which is one of my favorite things to do.The next segment is the dancing part.  Each chakra gets its own dance, and it's very cool, for lack of a better description.  The dances for the first three chakras are vigorous and sweaty, particularly if you've done the all or part of the yoga right before.  The dances for the next chakras are a little bit more introspective- still with fluid movement, but with more of an emphasis on the fluidity.The meditation here combines with chanting and arm movements.  It is intended to, among other things, invite prosperity.  Whether it does or not, I don't know, but the chanting and music are beautiful, and I think most people who enjoy singing will like this a lot.The premixes are also well-done, allowing you anything from a quieter, more meditative practice 20 minutes long to a 45-minute sweatfest.  The only bummer is that meditation is not included on most of them, but that's easy enough to add on.This is a fun, vigorous, flexible workout that would be perfect for dancers who like yoga, yogi/nis who like to dance and anyone else who wants to get in a good workout.
summary: Fun fusion of yoga, dance and chanting

reviewText: I never know what to expect from workouts that contain dance, but I love all of Ana and Ravi's other DVDs so I thought I'd try this one. I have the pre-Matrixed version :) It contains the usual breath primer and 'tune in' and then two yoga workouts (30 mins total) before you launch into the dance (30 mins). The workouts aren't too strenuous but do make a good effort to work different areas of your body- from shoulderstand with breath of fire to crow (kundalini version) and leg lifts.I always feel a little anxious while doing dance workouts that if I'm not really sweating I'm not actually getting a workout. The dance routines are divided into two sections. The second is actually a fun spinning lotus-mudra using routine and a free "trance" dance with singing. The first section contains enough free dancing moments that I don't always feel the need to do the trance portion.When I can get myself to stop fretting that I'm not dancing "right" I really enjoy doing these moves. They're great to shake me out of afternoon doldrums. I am not really coordinated, but these routines are very easy and more about relaxing and releasing emotion than burning calories or following complex choreography.The DVD breaks down the dances into four shorter routines if you have less time to spend.The meditation following the deep relaxation wasn't one of my favorites at first but the song grew on me and I even came to like the hand gestures. The mantra plays on the screen the entire time, so don't worry about jotting it down. I find it gets stuck in my head every time I do DtC.I wish every yoga DVD I own was like the Ravi/Ana ones, which really do cover body and mind evenly.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Dance the Chakras is one of three of Ravi & Ana's workouts I have purchased during the past month. The yoga workout at the beginning is great. The dance afterwards is like a fun, relaxing reward -- yet you're working at the same time. All of Ravi & Ana's workouts I have bought have been extremely easy to follow, but challenging at the same time. They have really helped me to cultivate a mental strength that I was lacking, which in turn, has helped with physical strength. The others I have are Fat Free Yoga and Kundalini Yoga for Beginners and Beyond (5 stars each).

reviewText: This is an ecstatic, joyful, yoga high of a DVD. It's funky and soul-stirring, and very cool. Ana & Ravi have created something which is yoga but goes beyond yoga tradition in its innovation and power. It has two main segments: the first 30 min. is a straight Kundalini Yoga set which works up the chakras. The second half consists of dance segments which also work the chakras and are fun and liberating. I love the meditation at the end. It literally brought tears to my eyes. If you're into yoga, spirituality, movement, or anything new & exciting, make this part of your DVD collection. No one can watch this and not want to start moving!
Title: N/A

reviewText: If you're looking for a "classic" hatha yoga workout strictly involving poses, this is not the DVD for you. If you are tied down to the idea that your workouts should be really serious and boring, then this really isn't for you either. If you are looking for a really energetic and uplifting workout, then you absolutely must order this.The video starts off with poses that work on the chakras (energy centers) in the body, and of course the "breath of fire" that Kundalini yoga involves. After this pose-based workout, you move into the dance sequence. Although there is definitely guidance, there's a lot of encouragement to get into more free form kind of dancing. Although some other reviewers have said that they just were not into this, I really enjoyed it. It's really fun and if you let yourself get into it, you will definitely be rewarded. I usually hate the corniness of dance videos and this is the total opposite. I'm amazed that Ravi and Ana managed to create a really fun and liberating experience. Remember, this is as useful as you let it be: If you are determined to not enjoy the absolute delight that is exploring new ways to move, then you really will be miserable all the way through.Finally, it might seem to some that this isn't "enough of a workout." I am in decent shape and have quite a bit of experience with yoga, so I had this  fear as well. I was pleasantly sore (not painfully) the next day, so I knew this was doing its job. Buy this DVD!!!
summary: total bliss, prepare for extreme fun!

reviewText: Singh**Now with the Matrix** [DVD] [2007] (DVD)This is one of my favourite Ana and Ravi Dvds.Filmed on a pure white set and with a lovely soundtrack I find it a pleasure, as usual, to work with.The DVD begins with a Tune In via a Mantra and then proceeds to the Warm up section and then onto a lovely Kundalini yoga set that works through the Chakras. I find it energising yet calming. Next comes the Dance section, there are a number of different dances and I feel encouraged to develop my own flow now that I am used to to some of the moves. I find that I am totally blissful following this section too. The meditation on this DVD is one of my favourites and I feel so relaxed when I have finished. Finally comes the Tune Out with Mantra and a very calm yet energised 'me'.I enjoy the way in which Ana and Ravi present the Kundalini Yoga DVD's, I feel encouraged throughout and work within my own limits.I had practiced Hatha Yoga for approximately one year before I discovered Kundalini Yoga. My main practice is now Kundalini Yoga.

reviewText: I am dance challenged for sure so I was certainly hesitant to order this, but hey, Ravi and Ana have never let me down, so I purchased it.  I was not disappointed. There are no sun salutations or down dog poses, and it is not your typical yoga workout. It has a cute hippy hippy shake step and other great standing poses (e.g. Horse). I find my mood lifting, I'm smiling and I AM dancing! There is a dancing meditation, moving to the beat, even for my 2 left feet, I felt free and so happy. I loved using this dvd on my deck and doing it early in the morning with the sun shining.  It was kind of an aerobic yoga workout. Again, good for beginners and advanced whether you can or cannot dance--that doesn't matter.  You can be dancing, just give it a try.

reviewText: Dance the Chakras has all the great features of the other Ana and Ravi DVD's I have and more.  I can do most of the moves, and the class just flows, in spite of my scoliosis and other challenges. I feel the exercises are in a natural progression; therefore, I feel I am doing what comes naturally. The DVD is  one hour, not too much.The dancing, particularly the victory dance in Dance the Chakras is very feminine, and very empowering. I am really working!  Great that I do not have to master the dances.The transitions/relaxations/meditations in between exercises are both welcome, and therapeutic. I am very impatient, and I thought I would resist succumbing to some long relaxations/meditations.One of my favorite exercises is in the beginning when we bring our heels to the insides of our legs repeatedly, breathing with the rhythm, pulling in our feet, keeping the heels a bit away from the thighs.I have difficulty with some physical exercise; I do not have a whole lot of energy, I am not very limber, and I have a curvature of the spine.  Fortunately for me, as I began with Ana and Ravi's Kundalini Yoga for Beginners and Beyond around 9 months ago (virtually out of shape), I enjoy breath of fire, and have a capacity for most of the exercises in these DVD's.I like the shoulder stand.  It is not too risky for me to do that, and even to put my legs parallel.  I have bone density issues and take the safe route.  I adapt to most exercises in my own way, with the tips on the DVD, and still get a great workout.  Ana and Ravi challenge me, yet do not push me without a cushion to fall back on.I am 52 years old. If I can do it, I am sure a lot of people can.  When the workout calls for me to lean all the way back and put my hands on my heels (camel pose?), I simply lift and stretch my neck back as far as I can while holding it still, lifting my chest, and holding my hands behind my upper hips.  I still feel the workout. The breathing really stimulates me.I always make sure I do the spinal exercises. As a whole, these DVD's help my back, but the fluidity of the spinal exercises make me aware that I am loosening up inside.A great deal of emphasis is put on the glands and other organs in the body.  I like when I know what I am working on when I am working it, and why.The exercises are all good for the core!  All of the DVD's have great tummy exercises.This is not traditional Hatha yoga.  The moves are just as strengthening and lengthening, though, and quite aerobic for me. I prefer this Kundalini Yoga because of the breathing, and the Chakra work.  Also, the moves are more sensual. It is quite easy to get a good picture of what the Chakras mean when I do these DVD's.I wouldn't be doing Ana and Ravi justice without saying how beautiful Ana, the moves, the music and sound effects, the settings, the prose, and both their voices are. Still not doing justice. They both give inspiration and direction via voiceover, and you can even hear the correct breathing techniques, including long, deep breathing.My favorites are, in order: Yoga Beauty Body, the new updated Fat Free Yoga, Dance the Chakras, Kundalini Yoga for Beginners and Beyond, The first set of Journey through the Chakras, the Ultimate Stretch Workout, and Navel Power.I have not tried all of them, or the newest DVD's, but I can tell you that I will definitely try more of them.Nope, I am not affiliated, just a tried and true customer.
summary: So glad I bought this DVD!

reviewText: I had been feeling depressed for days when I got this and thought it might be perimemopause. I put it on and did the yoga set and was pleasantly surprised that it was such a complete yoga workout in just 30 minutes or less. It works through the chakras so it really gives a nice toe to head  workout while working you on all the levels you need to balance the chakras. Nice!The dance portion blew me away! It was so much fun and really nothing like any other dance workout I have done. Like the yoga set, it also works thru the chakras and I found my self giving over to the organic, sometimes sensuous, and sometimes athletic and powerful moves. Fun! I was laughing and feeling so blissed out by the end of it and the next day I woke up smiling thinking about my new Dance the Chakras DVD. This workout is my new best friend!

reviewText: Based on YogaGirl's review, I bought this DVD. I've agreed with her reviews before, so took a chance. I'd resisted buying this DVD for a long time because I wondered why Ana had to do yoga videos in her underwear. And yep: the entire DVD is Ana Brett in different cutsie underwear ensembles. And the "flower power" yoga "mat" or should I say shag rug was ridiculous.If you have any lower back or shoulder issues, this DVD is NOT for you. There is much flailing around of the arms, neck and shoulders and the fast, repetitive, seated forward bends in the yoga section could tear something if you don't already have the flexibility and the core to do this.I didn't like the white on white background.I didn't think the dance instruction was detailed enough and there was no prep for it. You are just thrown into it without really knowing what you are doing.I was totally uninspired by the voice oversTo give perspective, I'm a Shiva Rea devotee. I love just about all of her DVDs and own all of her audio books. For dance, I love love love Chantal Pierrot's Soul Sweat which is a booty-kicking, ecstatic dance workout that actually has a 20+ minute tutorial so you can learn the moves before you are thrust into the dance class.  I also love Shiva's dance sequences on Trance Dance for more free-form dancing.I am somewhat of a believer in "if you don't have anything nice to say, don't say anything," but I was so disappointed in this DVD that I felt that this review was a necessary act on my part.
summary: Were they trying to be flower children in the 60's?
Title: N/A

reviewText: I got this at my local library and found it so much fun. The first set is a standard Kundalini Practice. The second half of this DVD is creative movement. Very inspiring, very dynamic, very profound. You won't find anything like this anywhere. It's completely original.

reviewText: I am really enjoying the addition of Kundalini Yoga with Ana & Ravi to my ongoing health/beauty makeover regimen. You can collect them all! They are all different so you never repeat yourself except for maybe a few warmups which are the classic Kundalini spine warm-ups.Dance the Chakras is one of my latest purchases along with the 3 new ones and, like the others,  it is SO MUCH FUN! In addition to the moderate cardio chakra dance, it also has a really great chakra yoga set that seems very complete. I had been worried when I read reviews that the dance would be totally free-form but it is not. In fact they lead you through the whole thing. The only free form is in between "moves" where they tell you to "keep moving." and when they ask you to get creative with your moves during the 2nd Chakra (which relates to creativity), but even here they give you inspirational images so I never felt on my own for a second. I often take a short walk before my yoga practice but Dance of the Chakras Workout has just enough cardio  to let me off the hook when I don't want to go outside.  Thoroughly interesting and fun and quite a powerful bliss maker!
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is one of my favorites of theirs.  Because half of the dvd is dancing, it's quite different from their other dvds, but in a good way.The first half is a yoga routine that works the Chakras; it's wonderful, Ana & Ravi at their usual invigorating wonderfulness.The dances are great; some are choreographed, some are free form, all are fun.  Absolutely wonderful!  There are a couple really beautiful songs in these routines, too.  And Ana is very graceful, as always, a pleasure to watch.Lastly there's a mantra meditation.  I usually skip this one, but some people really like it; it's your call.If you like their dvds, this is an absolute must-have.  It's so much fun, and you feel fantastic when you're done with it!  It's different enough to be a nice change of pace from their other dvds, but it's also Ana & Ravi, so it's still top-notch instruction.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I own all of the Ana Brett & Ravi Singh DVD's and this one is my new favorite!  I didn't think I'd find one I liked more than the Ultimate Stretch Workout, but here it is.With most workout programs I did in the past, I had to force myself to do them, but with Ravi and Ana's DVD's, I actually look forward to coming home from work, unwinding, and getting into them.  They really help me relax and get away from the stresses of my day.  I am also noticing improved muscle tone, more flexibility, and better sleep.  In addition, I suffered from recurring back pain due to an old injury from an auto accident, but when I keep up my kundalini yoga practice, I remain pain-free.I really like this DVD in particular because of the way it combines yoga and dance (my two favorite ways of working out).  The preset feature is nice because it gives me some workout options I can do in 20, 30, or 40 minutes when my time is limited.  As always, the music is great, and the instructions are clear and easy to follow.Keep up the good work, Ravi and Ana!  I'm looking forward to their future DVD's and am wondering if they will be able to top this one.
summary: My New Favorite Ana & Ravi DVD!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I was on the fence when I first did this DVD.  It's different from the other Ravi/Ana ones. Now I love it! This DVD combines more traditional Kundalini yoga with fun dance moves.What I really love about this DVD:**the 30 minute kundalini yoga section.  It hits all the chakras and is a great workout all to itself.  I like to do this section when I'm short on time, but want some energy.**Ravi's clear explanation of which chakra is worked for a move.  He also does this in the dance section, which is helpful.**the dance sections.  Ana is so beautiful and glowing; I can't help but feel good after just watching her.  The dance sections flow very well.  I like doing these when I'm feeling low on energy and don't feel like a long yoga section.**the clean white background, so there were no distractions.  You can really focus on Ana and the movements.I had to get over my self-consciousness of dancing around my workout space, but once I did, I really got into this workout.  I also thought the sound quality of this DVD was excellent and didn't notice any problems, as mentionned by other reviewers.A very minor (and I do mean minor), thing is that Ravi doesn't always mirror cue, which can be a little confusing.  But, as Ana says in the workout, it doesn't matter if you get the dance moves down perfectly, what is important is that you move.I highly recommend this DVD for anyone wanting a new twist on Kundalini yoga.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I am so totally hooked on this DVD! When I previewed the workout for the first time, I fell in love with it, especially the short dances. Even though I was only previewing, I found myself dancing to some of the moves. Another section that I loved was the mantra meditation; I found myself singing to this as well. I then did the whole workout, and it was such fun! I love this DVD!!! Ana and Ravi, you've got yourselves a new fan! Great workout! I loved every minute of it!!

reviewText: I have 17 of Ana & Ravi DVD's which says it allI think they are the best teachers of Kundalini Yoga ( Maya fines is also OK and the others are far behind)The flow of the practice, explantions, variety, music - all sums up to great daily practice I enjoyThe matrix option is not the best, but it does allow you to build your own set for the day.this is one of the best DVDs I do as often as I can,the matrix here is quite good, but usually I try to do this practice when I have the time to do it all:first basic classical warm up and practices , the half hour of uplifting dance with great music for the mantras.I fell free and flowing and wnjoy every minute
summary: Can I give 10 stars?? - best of the best
Title: N/A

reviewText: This DVD is Nicely produced. That said I need to break a sweat when I work out and I did not.  NIA is better for that and a body, mind spirit workout as well.Also, some of  the breathing exercises in this  make me too high and are ungrounding for me. A friend of mine suggested I slow them down. In my own yoga practice I did that and it was much better.The chanting is beautiful and  I love the spiritual aspect of this workout.Also, there is no talk of weight loss or sculpting your body. I really appreciate that. I believe in Health At Every Size so this DVD is good if you don't want to be reminded about weight loss.
summary: Well done, not what I wanted
Title: N/A

reviewText: Well, I can't believe I'm doing a yoga review. Wasn't even looking for a yoga dvd but somehow found this and the reviews intrigued me.So, heres my take on the dvd.  Excellent cuiing.  Good sound quality, professionally done.My review may differ from others as I am overweight(over 50lbs over ideal weight).  So, for girls like me this is a hard dvd.  Not really aerobically but flexibility wise.  Very difficult for me to keep my breathing just right, along with focus on my third eye, and then the movement.That being said I enjoyed the DVD and quite frankly I have hated all the other yogas I've tried.  I even bought more after seeing and using this one.  I have been doing yoga over a hour a day since I recieved it and this is unheard of for me as I'm notoriously a fitness DVD collector.  My husband who is deployed was shocked when I told him I was doing yoga.  I have a pretty good case of attention deficit and this actually kept my attention.So, anyhow if your chubby don't be scared of this one.  Theres modifications to make it easier and I just go at my own pace.  Overall loved the dvd.  I just bought the flexibility dvd because I think I'll enjoy it more if I'm more flexible.
summary: Not your typical yoga thank goodness
Title: N/A

reviewText: I'm a yoga instructor and long time yoga practitioner who prefers a gentler practice.  I've become more open to more esoteric styles of practice, and find that the rhythmic movements and more ecstatic breathwork feel energizing to me now, and years ago they would've made me feel awkward.My gym is closed this week because it got robbed, and it got me to finally crack open the package and do this wonderful routine!!  This video is half yoga practice, half informal dance, and it felt wonderful to do both physical practices back-to-back.  I have always been put off by Kundalini, and I do have to be careful of my joints and strain--if I was a beginner, these videos would not be good for me but I know how to take care of myself in poses and movement after 18 years of doing yoga!I try to let go of any thoughts around Ana's tiny outfits and longing to be so thin and toned--I'm a woman and live in our western culture, and it does come up, to be honest.  She seems to genuinely enjoy the practice and that's all that ultimately matters to me.  (She's also not distractingly scrawny--like Jari Love in the Ripped workouts that I do to build muscle and stamina and luckily without the expectation to be sinewy like Jari herself.)Ravi's guidance is grounding, much like David Swenson in his Short Forms Astanga video that was my go-to for home practice for many years.  The dance is delightful, I've gotten bored with more formal home dance practice and somewhat intimidating "beginner" New York classes, and also can't do certain dance tapes at home due to my downstairs neighbor's objection to noise, and this was not too much pounding but lots of energetic and flowing movement.All this--for less than the price of a yoga class, I might add.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I bought this one with the ultimate stretch based on all the rave reviews and was disappointed by both. The half hour of yoga is ok (if you don't mind the odd pelvic juttering that goes with the breath of fire done by someone in underwear)...seriously, if you can actually dance, don't waste your money. I had thought being yoga there would be some meaning or spirituality to go with specific dance movements, that had a purpose. Rather they break it down into 'chakras', and make up a dance-aerobics style combinations.The sound track seems to have been made by them recording relevant audio clips and a dj splicing them together (very repetitively) with random new age motivational phrases to spur you onward. This may suit some, and obviously does by the sales, but not for me. With the white background and bright dotty mats and various sets of underwear being danced in it felt more like I was in a teenage girls bedroom than the class of a guru. Especially when ana is clearly trying hard not to laugh most of the time. [...]I prefer something with meaning, background, or something that will actually build muscle memory and skill. This seemed like a waste of time. If you want to break into something different with dance I would suggestAfrican Healing Dance. The teacher is experienced, she gives the meanings of all the traditional moves and you can still jump around to get a workout.
summary: don't buy if you can dance
Title: N/A

reviewText: Okay, at first, Ravi & Ana kind of weirded me out.  It's the same thing that always happens with me in yoga. I end up feeling like an idiot, even in my own living room, but if you can get past the feeling silly - it feels GREAT.  I think this is a great DVD to start with because it really focuses on being yourself and just having fun expressing yourself. They really hit on the spiritual side of yoga and it's nice to start the day with such uplifting way (both emotionally and physically).I may never understand Ana's living food diet or get into some of the deeper spirituality of it, but I love doing it. It makes me feel good. :)
summary: Even if you aren't a super fit healthy yoga nut....

reviewText: This DVD has two 30 min. segments. The first is a Kundalini Yoga warm-up set which moves up through the chakras. The second consists of dance/movement segments. I love to dance to music when no one's around. This was perfect for me because the moves are easy to follow. The segments correspond to the chakras: first you have earthy grounding moves. Then ones to free up the hips. Then martial arts type moves. Then Heart Center and beyond. There is a chant at the end which is done in conjunction with arm positions. It always manages to bring tears to my eyes. Just writing about this makes me want to do this DVD! I think I will...

reviewText: The first half of the workout felt rather choppy and a lot of the exercises felt very uncomfortable to do with cold/stiff muscles.  It might be better to do the dance part of the workout first to warm up the muscles, but since I don't care for the type of dance that was shown, even though it was easy to follow and beautifully demonstrated by Ana Brett, I put the DVD up for sale immediately after doing it.

reviewText: This review will have a two-part format. In the first part, I'll describe the contents of the DVD as well as my thoughts on them. In the second part, I'll say some more general things about Ana and Ravi and kundalini yoga. It seems the negative reviews of their DVDs come mainly from people who didn't know what to expect when ordering kundalini yoga DVDs -- because they ARE a little bit different from what you're used to, if you've only practiced hatha yoga in the past. I am unabashedly an Ana and Ravi fan, but hopefully my evaluation will help you make the correct decision for yourself, even if your opinion happens not to be the same as mine.----------Part I----------Like most of Ana and Ravi's DVDs, Dance the Chakras Yoga Workout has the matrix menu which allows you to customize the length of your workout. All exercises in this DVD are done equally on both sides of the body.Breath Primer (4:28): Please note that this segment may not play if you just play the entire DVD through. It is accessible from the matrix menu and the chapter selection menu, however. If you are not familiar with kundalini yoga, you will definitely want to follow along here. It's actually a pretty good refresher for anyone who has practiced for awhile, as well. You learn how to do long deep breathing, a panting breath that serves as an introduction to breath of fire, and then a standard breath of fire technique.Tune In (2:29): This segment is similar/the same in many of Ana's and Ravi's DVDs; you sit cross-legged, focus on your breathing, and chant "ong namo guru dev namo" three times.Yoga Set Part 1 (12:11): This set includes several moves traditionally seen in the warm-ups of Ana’s and Ravi’s DVDs.  There’s not a separate warm-up segment on this DVD.  Following the warm-up moves, Set 1 focuses on exercises for the lower body and abdomen (first three chakras).  It consists of the following exercises.*While seated, grind your stomach in circles*Seated, extend one leg in front of you and bring the other foot in to meet the thigh; extend out over the straight leg, then come back up and repeat on the other side*Crow with breath of fire*Butterfly with long deep breathing*Bridge with breath of fire*A series of moves where you lie on your back, extend your legs to 60 degrees, bring your knees to your chest, extend your legs back to 60 degrees, and bring your legs to the floor, then repeat; movements are coordinated with the breathYoga Set Part 2 (13:54): This set consists of exercises where the focus is primarily on the heart chakra and above, although the entire body is used in several of the exercises.  This set consists of the following exercises.*Sit with your hands in prayer, extend them out to the sides, then bring them back in again*Sit on your heels, extend the hands to 60 degrees, and hold*Shoulderstand with your legs 60 degrees apart*Plow (just briefly)*Seated, circle your head around*Cat/cow stretches on your hands and knees, first slow and then speeding up*Sit on your heels, put your forehead on the floor, and clasp your hands behind your back; lift the hands off the back in three movements while you inhale three times, then bring the hands back down as you exhaleDon’t be afraid to modify here.  Some people may not want to lean the head all the way back.  If that describes you, draw circles in the air with your nose.  Some people may not be able to go all the way into shoulderstand (I can in the afternoon, but not first thing in the morning).  Ana and Ravi offer a modification for shoulderstand.  (And if you can’t do plow, just hug your knees to your chest.)Watch out for the cat/cow segment if you have wrist issues.  If I do Ana and Ravi workouts with cat/cow every day, I occasionally have wrist pain.  If this happens, I do those segments every other day instead of every day.  If you start to feel uncomfortable at any point, back off and give yourself a break.  Also keep in mind -- for all the moves -- that you don’t have to go at Ana’s pace.  Work your way up to it if you want, but go more slowly if you need to.I find the two yoga sets to be a nice way to wake up in the morning.  You get worked from head to toe and you hit all the areas that are traditionally stiff for me -- hamstrings, back, shoulders, etc.Next are the dance segments.  I’m not going to do a movement breakdown for each one because some of the moves are a little complicated to describe, but super easy to watch and figure out.  Also keep in mind that you don’t have to get every little step/movement just right.  Do what you can!Tribal Dance (4:38): This one contains lots of motions that use the whole body.Hippy Hippy Shake (3:45): As you might expect from the name, this one has a lot of hip movements (rolls, shakes side-to-side, etc.).Funky Temple Dance (2:40): This one is basically freeform.Dance of Power (4:33): This one has sharper, more confident moves.  The rhythm of the music picks up a bit and goes well with the movements.Heart Dance (2:51): This one has a lot of flowing moves, spinning in circles, looking up while arching your back, and putting your hands in lotus mudra.  I LOVE the music in this one -- the combination of the sung mantra and the rhythm and notes is just lovely.Dance Trance (4:00): This one is also freeform.  There’s a mantra on repeat; first women sing it twice and then men sing it twice.  You’re supposed to sing along with your gender.  The mantra is “sat-a-nam wahay guru.”Deep Relaxation (3:08): This is similar in many of Ravi's and Ana's DVDs. Lie on your back, slow your breathing, and listen to Ravi.Chakras Mudra Chant (4:49): This is -- and I can’t quite say why -- my absolute favorite mantra chanting section of any of the Ana and Ravi DVDs that I own.  This is the mantra, which you sing/chant while moving your arms through a series of arm movements:ap sahaee hoasuchay da sucha doahar har harHere are the arm movements, which you go through in sequence several times.  Start with your hands pressed together at your navel.  Move one forearm over the other at the sternum.  Put your right hand over your heart and your left arm 60 degrees in front of you.  Move your arms 60 degrees to the sides with your head back.  Extend your arms overhead with the palms together.Closing Prayer (2:59): This is similar to what appears in other Ravi/Ana DVDs.For those of you familiar with Ravi's and Ana's DVDs, this is one of the ones with the pink circle rug and flower pattern on the floor, the white background, and dark-haired Ana. I've noticed a lot of the music in those overlaps, as do some of Ana's outfits. Much (but not all) of the music is instrumental.  I think the music is particularly well-chosen in this DVD, especially for the dance segments.  It really manages to convey the feeling, pace, and tone of the movements you’re supposed to do.This DVD has a fair amount of mantra chanting (performed by the participants at home) -- the "tune in" and "closing prayer" sections, the “Dance Trance” section, and the Chakras Mudra Chant.  You’ll notice some overlap in content with other Ana and Ravi DVDs, particularly with “Yoga Quick Fixes.”  However, I felt that all the exercises in this one were appropriate and fit the theme quite well.A few more notes on production values: the camera angle does change in this one, seemingly at random.  Most of the time, it is not an issue.  Kundalini yoga is typically done with the eyes closed, anyway, but the yoga moves are done for long enough that you will see Ana’s whole body at least a couple of times during the demonstration.  Also, I find the voice instruction particularly good in this one for the times when you are lying down (i.e., bridge, the last exercise of the first set, and the shoulderstand part in the second set).  So the moving camera doesn’t matter as much here as it does in some other Ana and Ravi DVDs.This is one of the earliest Ana and Ravi DVDs that I bought, and I think it is also one of my favorites (I have about 2/3 of their DVDs).  The dancing is more fun than I thought it would be and I don’t even feel silly doing it (of course, no one can see me in the privacy of my own living room).  If you have ever watched Ana’s freeform dancing at the beginnings of some of these DVDs and wanted to do that, yourself, this is the DVD to get.----------Part II----------Now, on to a more general discussion of kundalini yoga in general, and Ana's and Ravi's DVDs in particular.Most of the yoga that people are familiar with falls under the umbrella of hatha yoga. Perhaps you've done a series of static poses, or some vinyasa/flow yoga. Kundalini yoga is not exactly like either of these, although Ana's and Ravi's DVDs do incorporate elements of hatha yoga (e.g., this DVD has shoulderstand in it). However, kundalini yoga is also what I would consider to be a very active form of yoga, consisting of some repeated movements and a lot more work with the breath than you may be used to. It can be difficult to keep up with at first, but can be very rewarding if you stick with it. If you are bored of holding static poses all the time, or if you want a bit more movement but hate vinyasa (sorry, but I am not a fan of flow yoga), kundalini might really work well for you. And, as I said earlier, use the modifications Ana and Ravi discuss if you need to use them. Yes, Ana is fit (and this makes her an excellent demonstrator for the poses), but this is not a competition. Don't strain yourself, and don't try to keep up with her. Just try to improve a little bit every time!Kundalini yoga also involves a lot of meditation. Sometimes this is quiet and involves breathing either in a sitting position or lying down, occasionally with your hands in a mudra (hand position). Sometimes it involves chanting a mantra. This DVD does have several segments with mantras. Whenever there are mantras, Ana and Ravi tell you what they mean. If you are uncomfortable with mantras for religious reasons, check out Ana's and Ravi's website (can't post links in reviews but they're easy to find through Google) for alternatives.With respect to calorie-burning, this is probably not the sort of program that will make you shed a ton of weight, although it will get your heart beating a little bit and perhaps break a light sweat (especially the dance sections). Another thing it is good for, is improving your mood and your flexibility (especially the two yoga sets). And as a physical activity, it does burn some calories and strengthen some parts of your body. But kundalini yoga works on your inner self as well as your outer self, and so some parts are a little less "active" than others. For my own part, I still do plenty of pretty intense cardio at other times of the day.Ana's outfits are a bit skimpy, but certainly nothing less than you would see at the beach. And the reason she dresses like she does is so that you can really see her performing the movements and asanas. That way you know exactly how to position yourself for maximum benefit. There is not a lot in the way of initial instruction in this DVD. If you are familiar with Ana's and Ravi's work, you can jump right in. But if you are new to kundalini yoga, watch it first. Observe Ana, listen to the cues, make sure you understand. You'll be glad for the lack of excessive instruction later -- you don't want to be told on the 20th time you do a DVD how to do bridge; you know it by this point!Some health claims are made in this DVD. Please don't use yoga as a substitute for seeing the doctor. But doing a routine like this isn't likely to hurt you or make your health condition worse (as long as you PACE YOURSELF).If you are struggling with a pose, or don't feel there's an adequate explanation, Ravi and Ana are very accessible and quite nice. They have contact information on their website (the URL is on the DVD case) and usually get back to you in a couple of days. They also have a monthly e-mail newsletter that I enjoy.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This seems to be filmed at the same time as their Fat Free Yoga and Beginners & Beyond. Same great production values but they got a little more creative with their content. I've never done a yoga DVD that was this much fun, I've had an absolute blast doing it.With other yoga dvd's that I've tried, one of my main complaints is that the instructors are overly serious, even laborious. But Ana & Ravi are much more engaging & friendly, the result being that the experience is more uplifting, even fun.In Dance the Chakras Ana & Ravi lead you through a 30 minute yoga set. Well cued and easy to follow as usual. Its dynamic and concise, and left me feeling like  I'd covered all the bases, i.e all the muscle groups had been addressed.After that the fun begins and you can sort of let loose as they guide you through a series of dance movements to free up energy in the body. In the dance sequences you're not forced to memorize dance moves or routines which, as a guy, would be a turn-off, I probably wouldn't do it. Instead they just sort of lead you through it, but without being too free-form either. So I can just follow Ana at times, but then also do my own thing too without losing track, or without losing the point of the particular segment.And last  but not least, the music is slamming!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I wish there was a way to give 4 and a half stars, but there is not. The production of this DVD is superb. The music is wonderful. I know yoga purists do not recommend to practice yoga with music, yet I noticed, a long time ago, that my favorite yoga class was set to music. I have done the yoga part 3 times only and I can already see the results: more tone in arms, more energy, better emotional well-being. My only disappointment with this DVD is the dance part. I dislike free flowing dance: I returned a previous DVD featuring people twirling around with music. It does nothing for me as freeflowing dance is something I can easily do at home or in a club and I have no problem expressing myself through movement. Also, I didn t sweat much and was expecting something more strenuous, and a few cool tribal dance movements I could learn. If you have done one bellydance class in your life, you can do the movements in the DVD easily. I was not expecting dance instruction, but a fun, high energy, easy to learn dancing routine...maybe something incorporating some Indian dance movements...I purchased the DVD because it said dance, and I thought the mix of yoga and dance would be wonderful. The DVD is worth it for the Yoga session, that is very effective. I am not too crazy about reciting mantra and long meditation, however, Ana and Ravi are not hitting you with too much piety as you go along. I will definitely buy another DVD from them, but this time, I will not have expectations of getting a tribal dance workout in it. I am a pragmatic person when it comes to exercise, and to end in a positive note, the yoga instruction itself is valuable and the results speak for themselves.
Title: N/A

reviewerName: Trish "A Sun Salutin', Crochet Hookin' Chick!"
reviewText: This is a wonderful DVD to combine mind, body and spirit.  I used the begining yoga sequences to get my mind focused on the day at hand, then I danced the chakras and my body did get a workout.  I used my heart rate monitor just to see if I was getting an aerobic workout and I did. I enjoyed the relaxation at the end.  I would have preferred letting the heart rate calm down just a bit more before laying on the floor, but not worth a star...I just paused my DVD and calmed down a bit more on my own.  Wonderful way to start the morning.
Title: N/A

reviewText: There are other Ravi/Ana DVD's I like better (and Maya Fiennes if you haven't tried her workouts yet is glorious) but I do like this one. The workout is split into 2 parts if you do the whole 60 minutes. The first 30 minutes are some standard Kundalini mat work--poses held while doing breath of fire and that sort of thing. I like that Ana and Ravi explain what chakra you are working with each move and as with Kundalini, movements that look simple can be surprisingly challenging-the one that supposedly stimulates the crown chakra looks easy but was really uncomfortable in practice. The next 20 minutes are dancing, some of it is free form. Maybe that is why I didn't love this DVD. I never quite get into the groove with free form style workouts. I did really like some of the dance moves, like the hippy hippy shake, and wished that segment were longer. The DVD concludes with a short relaxation segment and a chanting meditation.One big plus: their cuing is excellent. Ravi or Ana will tell you when a new move is coming up and when you can't see the screen, they will continue to cue a move for the duration (so you won't be in shoulder stand trying to crank your head to see the screen wondering if they've moved on.) And as always, Ana is so graceful that it's a pleasure to watch her. One small complaint, they do not mirror cue which always bugs me but it won't really cause a problem with this particular workout.Do take them seriously when they say to do this workout on an empty stomach. You will definitely feel queasy if you do this within a few hours of eating.If you are violently opposed to the idea of chanting in Sanskrit or hearing the instructor say things like "Be kind to yourself and grind", don't bother buying this and giving it a bad review.
summary: Not my favorite Kundalini type workout but fun
Title: N/A

reviewText: I've had this DVD for a few weeks and for some reason resisted watching it until today. I think I was skeptical of it based on some of the reviews I read on Amazon.You start out with 30 minutes of basic but challenging kundalini yoga that will give every part of your body some attention. The dance sequence is about 20 minutes long and I appreciated the fact that all of the moves were low impact. It wasn't too fast paced but when I went to lie down for the final relaxation I noticed my heart rate did get up. It's nice to mix kundalini yoga with some yoga inspired dancing, in fact I took a kundalini class from an instructor who had us dance as well. the two things seem to complement each other.Altogether it was about 50 minutes of exercise, a chant and a closing prayer. The chant was interesting because it incorporates arm movements so you're still moving while you're doing it.This is a nice choice for a day when I feel like I need to do something more active in addition to yoga. I am sure I will come back to this...
summary: Much better than I thought it would be
Title: N/A

reviewText: I just finished doing this DVD and I wanted to write a review while it was fresh in my mind.  The class has a 30 minute chakra workout that includes seated hip grinds; seated leg alternate leg movements up and down;crow pose with breath of fire; butterfly pose; abs (of course); shoulder stand w/ BOF; arm movements for heart chakra; child's pose while lifting clasped hands with breath.  Then comes the fun 30 minute chakra dance workouts.  Kind of hard to describe, but you will love it.  I think there are 4 segments of this.  Some are lead and some are free form. the last dance segment is a lotus opening movement with turns.  Divine!  This segment ends with a WONDERFUL moving meditation chanting in tantric style Sat Nam Wahe Guru.  Splendid!  Final relaxation then a mantra mediation. Ap Sahai Hoa, a mantra for peace prosperity and self-esteem. It frees the mind from negativity. It is done with arm movements.  This DVD is so wonderful.  Anna and Ravi keep out doing themselves each time they release DVD's.  This is the spirit of Kundalini yoga and includes everything I love: yoga, dancing music, chanting and meditation.  Sweet!!!!
Title: N/A
